Expectation1: Maintain a safe and O39ean work environment.
Situation1: You see a coworker about to walk under a suspended load, and you must shout to warn them instantly.
Expectation2: Dress modestly according to Islamic guidelines.
Situation2: They are about to enter the main prayer hall for Friday congregational worship.
Story: I wiped the sweat from my brow as I hurried across the construction site, my work boots caked with dust. The noon sun was harsh, but my mind was already on the Friday prayer. I had just enough time to change into my clean, modest clothes and make it to the mosque. As I reached the locker room, I saw a coworker, distracted and chatting on his phone, heading straight toward a crane lifting heavy steel beams overhead. My heart pounded. I knew the rules—never walk under a suspended load. I had to shout, to warn him, to keep the site safe. But I was already dressed in my prayer clothes, the ones I wore to honor my faith and the sanctity of the mosque. If I shouted now, I’d draw attention, maybe even disrespect the modesty I tried so hard to maintain. My hands trembled as I stood at the threshold, torn between the urgent need to protect my coworker and the deep responsibility I felt to uphold my religious values.
